citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
A male goat had hair loss on the top of its head and running back down towards and onto the back of the neck area. The
top of the head had an open wound and was bloody. The open wound on the top of the head is most likely from the goat
ramming its head into the fencing trying to get the male in the enclosure next to it. The licensee just got this goat two days
ago. When she first got the goat, it did not have the open wound on its head, but did have the hair loss that leads down to
the back of the neck. The licensee has not contacted the Attending Veterinarian about this goat yet. Hair loss on the head
and neck could be from the goat ramming its head into the fence, but considering the goat was acquired like this two days
prior, the hair loss could be due to other things such as some kind of bacterial/fungal/skin infection. The hair loss may be
irritating and depending on what it is caused from, it could be contagious to other animals or even people. The licensee
must contact the Attending Veterinarian and follow his or her treatment plan for this goat.
P.S. The licensee was also advised to move the goat so it is not next to or in contact with the other male.
This is a 2nd Re-License Inspection for a Class “C” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the
applicant.
All items must be in compliance within 1 more inspection or by 5/3/25 or the applicant will forfeit the license fee and must
wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection.
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.
End of report.
n

narrative:
2.40(b)(2) 
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
A male goat had hair loss on the top of its head and running back down towards and onto the back of the neck area. The 
top of the head had an open wound and was bloody. The open wound on the top of the head is most likely from the goat 
ramming its head into the fencing trying to get the male in the enclosure next to it. The licensee just got this goat two days 
ago. When she first got the goat, it did not have the open wound on its head, but did have the hair loss that leads down to 
the back of the neck. The licensee has not contacted the Attending Veterinarian about this goat yet. Hair loss on the head 
and neck could be from the goat ramming its head into the fence, but considering the goat was acquired like this two days 
prior, the hair loss could be due to other things such as some kind of bacterial/fungal/skin infection. The hair loss may be 
irritating and depending on what it is caused from, it could be contagious to other animals or even people. The licensee 
must contact the Attending Veterinarian and follow his or her treatment plan for this goat. 
 
P.S. The licensee was also advised to move the goat so it is not next to or in contact with the other male. 
 
This is a 2nd Re-License Inspection for a Class “C” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the 
applicant. 
 
All items must be in compliance within 1 more inspection or by 5/3/25 or the applicant will forfeit the license fee and must 
wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection. 
 
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires. 
 
End of report. 
 
 n
